#Text=Boston/South End
#Text=Possessing the largest Victorian row house district in the country , the South End is one of Boston 's most popular places .

#Text=After many homes underwent renovation in the 1960s , upscale restaurants and art galleries sprang up , and the area has attracted a diverse blend of families , young professionals , a gay and lesbian community and a thriving artistic center .
#Text=Understand
#Text=In response to the crowded conditions throughout the downtown and Beacon Hill neighborhoods , the city of Boston decided to fill in tidal marshes to the south .
#Text=Beginning sometime around the 1830s , a new inner city residential neighborhood was envisioned , with a large and stable tax base to draw from .
#Text=Architect Charles Bulfinch was hired , who oversaw the infill of land and created a series of residential parks .
#Text=Inspired by English residential town squares , most greenspace is artfully landscaped and ringed with attractive cast iron fencing .
#Text=The buildings here were designed to be uniform five-story bowfront structures .
#Text=To further accentuate the visual unity of the area , Bullfinch called for a common palette of brick , slate , limestone , and cast iron elements to be used .
#Text=At first , a burgeoning middle class moved to the South End including business owners .

#Text=As new housing developments opened up , however , the Back Bay and Roxbury soon became the " it " neighborhoods , and the South End would slide into a tenement district by the end of the 19th century .
#Text=Close to good railroad jobs and now more affordable , the South End quickly began to attract African-American families , and became a center of black middle class Boston life and culture .
#Text=Known as a " Jazz Mecca " for the first half of the 20th century , when musicians like Duke Ellington and Cab Calloway performed in a myriad of area clubs .
#Text=More and more buildings fell into disrepair , and by the 1960s absentee landlordism was rampant and the neighborhood was one of the poorest of the city .
#Text=At this point , Boston 's city planners once again stepped in , knocking down blocks of dilapidated structures and replacing them with housing projects and areas of light industry .
#Text=It was an imperfect solution , but it mostly worked out , and set the groundwork for the beautiful and diverse community residing in the South End today .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=The Orange Line is going to be your best option for accessing most of the South End .
#Text=The Back Bay and Massachusetts Ave stations bring you close to the action .
#Text=While the Ruggles station is in the neighborhood , most of the attractions are further north .
#Text=The Green Line roughly parallels the Orange in this area , but the stations are slightly further away .
#Text=One stop on the Red Line , Broadway , is great for accessing SoWa market and all the new developments in the South End 's northeastern corner .
#Text=If the suburbs and beyond are where you 're leaving/arriving from , Back Bay Station is for you .
#Text=On the Commuter Rail , the Providence/Stoughton , Framinghham/Worcester , Needham , and Franklin lines all stop here .
#Text=This is also a main stop for Amtrak with Acela Express , Northeast Regional , and Lake Shore Limited trains all heading further afield .
#Text=This station is also the first stop for the #39 bus , which takes you south past the museums and into Jamaica Plain .
#Text=Another great option is the Silver Line , a bus rapid transit service running through the center of the neighborhood .
#Text=From north to south the stops are : Herald St , East Berkeley St , Union Park St , Newton St , Worcester Sq , Massachusetts Avenue , and finally Lenox St .
#Text=This bus can be helpful , as it passes by all the big commercial areas in the South End .
#Text=By foot
#Text=This is really the best way to see this minute neighborhood , barely over a mile across .
#Text=As a point of reference , traversing the neighborhood would take the average person less than 30 minutes on foot .
#Text=Walking from the Orange Line Mass Ave station , to the I-90 I-93 overpass next to downtown .
#Text=By car
#Text=Strongly not recommended .
#Text=There are no parking garages in the South End , and virtually all on street parking is resident only .
#Text=You 'd have to park in a different neighborhood and walk in anyway , so what 's the point of driving ?
#Text=See
#Text=There 's not much to see in the South End in particular .
#Text=The neighborhood is quite small and beautiful , so your best bet may be to just go for a stroll .
#Text=The area has some of the most wonderfully restored brownstones , they really pop offset against the dramatic backdrop of Back Bay 's skyscrapers .
#Text=You will find scores of gardens and small parks tucked between the warren of intimate ( and occasionally cobblestoned ) streets .
#Text=Evenings here are great for walking as well , as gas lamps flicker to life and light your path across care-worn bricks .
#Text=Site of Boston town gate ( T : Tufts Medical Center ) .
#Text=24 hours daily .
#Text=At one time this route was the only way in or out of Boston .
#Text=Still an isthmus in the early 17th century , the town was almost entirely surrounded by water .
#Text=Here at the corner of Washington and E Berkeley streets Mayflower era colonists built gated earthworks to keep out natives and unwanted animals .
#Text=A gallows stood outside the gate , where thieves and murderers would be executed .
#Text=These defenses were constantly being improved , especially during the colonial era .
#Text=As time went on , however , the water was filled in by earth and the gate lost its importance .
#Text=Today there is no plaque or other signifier of this important spot , only a few signs at the nearby bus station .
#Text=This noisy street corner could be easily skipped , or it could be a heady spot to contemplate the passage of time .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Galleries
#Text=This is a smattering of the galleries the South End has on offer .
#Text=They can be found throughout the neighborhood , with the greatest number being concentrated in the SoWa Market area .
#Text=Naturally .
#Text=Its best to visit on the weekends , and better still on market days .
#Text=L'Attitude Gallery , 460 Harrison Ave #8A ( SoWa ) .

#Text=M Fine Arts Galerie , 61 Thayer St ( SoWa ) ,  +1617 450-0700 .
#Text=10AM-6PM daily .
#Text=First established in Soho , New York , it offers the best selection of contemporary European painters to its clients .
#Text=M Fine Arts Galerie was established in 2016 , continuing the work of Axelle after the previous owner passed away .

#Text=You will find an ever-evolving selection of new , museum-quality paintings here , due to the exclusive representation of many European artists such as Patrick Pietropoli , Fabienne Delacroix , Andr Bourri , Brian Stephens and Diana Nicosia .
